SEARCH
Package com.oblong.jelly

Class Slaw

java.lang.Object
com.oblong.jelly.Slaw
All Implemented Interfaces:
HasToSlaw, Iterable<Slaw>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Protein, SlawArray, SlawList, SlawMap, SlawString
@Immutable public abstract class Slaw extends Object implements Iterable<Slaw>, HasToSlaw
Slaw instances constitute the components of Proteins and wrap strongly typed data values.

As we'll see, the type of the value hold by a Slaw is fully determined by its ilk (as enumerated by SlawIlk and, when applicable, its numeric ilk (enumerated by NumericIlk. The class interface includes a family of predicates to check for the concrete type (or, as we'll call it, ilk) of the Slaw instance at hand. Once you know its ilk, you can access the actual value wrapped by a Slaw (in the form of a Java native value) using one of the emit methods in this class. Each of these methods is applicable, in general, only to a subset of the possible Slaw ilks (e.g. emitBoolean() makes no sense when applied to a Slaw with ilk MAP), and will throw an (unchecked) UnsupportedOperationException if called on the wrong Slaw instance; thus, the recommended pattern is either to guard their usage by a call to the corresponding type predicate, as in 

   if (s.isNumber()) x = s.emitLong();
   // ...
   if (!s2.isBoolean()) return x;
   // ...
   foo(s2.emitBoolean());
or wrap the call inside a try/catch clause. The method documentation below details, for each of the potentially illegal operations, the safe ilk subsets, as well as the type tests that can be used as guards.

Several of the available Slaw ilks represent composite types. You can access the components of a Slaw instance in a traditional index based fashion by means of nth and count. But Slaw also also implements Iterable, so that you can iterate over the sub-slawx using new-style for loops or the Iterator interface. Since Slaw instances are immutable, the latter does not support the remove operation.

As a convenience, using the sub-slaw traversal APIs on atomic Slaw instances is supported: with regard to those methods, an atomic Slaw is considered as a container with one element, which is itself. This convenience comes with the risk of introducing infinite loops in your programs if you happen to recursively iterate over sub-slawx: such iterations should always be guarded by a call to isComposite().

Since this is an abstract class, a host of factory methods is provided to let you construct new Slaw instances out of native Java values and/or other slawx. In the case of non-atomic numeric Slaw (complex numbers, vectors and multivectors) constructors taking generic Slaw arguments, the latter must be of a numeric ilk; otherwise, a non-checked exception will be thrown. So it pays to make sure that arguments passed to those methods are of the correct ilk. Note that all atomic numeric Slaw share a common ilk, NUMBER, which is further refined (in terms of signedness and width) by an associated NumericIlk: there's a well defined notion of coercion between Slaw numbers, given by an ordering of their numeric ilk from INT8 up to FLOAT64, and that coercion is applied by the factory methods of composite numeric slawx.

So, strictly speaking, the real type of a Slaw instance is determined by its ilk and its numeric ilk. Composite numeric slawx inherit their numeric ilk from that of their components (which will always be the same: the factory methods will take care of that). Non-numeric slawx have null as their NumericIlk.

The use of Slaw instead of native Java data types will be conductive to a dynamic style in your programs, with the flexibility (and drawbacks) offered by run-time checks and late binding. Alternatively, you can use Slaw simply as a serialization format to communicate and exchange data with pools, quickly de-marshal the proteins you obtain, and stick to a more conventional, statically typed style in the rest of your program.

See Also:
  • SlawIlk
  • NumericIlk

  • Constructor Details

      protected Slaw()

  • Method Details

    • ilk

      public abstract SlawIlk ilk()
      The ilk (or kind) of this slaw. The return value of this method is guaranteed to be non-null.

    • numericIlk

      public abstract NumericIlk numericIlk()
      For Slaw instances whose ilk is numeric (i.e., those for which SlawIlk.isNumeric() returns true), this method will return its numeric ilk. The real type of a numeric Slaw is determined by both its ilk and its numeric ilk.

      For non-numeric slawx, this method returns null.

      See Also:
      • isNumeric()

    • is

      public final boolean is(SlawIlk ilk)
      Convenience method that checks this Slaw's ilk against the provided one. If ilk is null, this method will return false.

    • isAtomic

      public final boolean isAtomic()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is atomic, using SlawIlk.isAtomic().

    • isComposite

      public final boolean isComposite()
      Just the negation of isAtomic()

    • isNil

      public final boolean isNil()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.NIL

    • isBoolean

      public final boolean isBoolean()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.BOOL

    • isString

      public final boolean isString()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.STRING

    • isNumeric

      public final boolean isNumeric()
      Checks whether this Slaw belongs to one of the numeric ilks. Numeric ilks are defined by the predicate SlawIlk.isNumeric().

      Numeric slawx can be either atomic (SlawIlk.NUMBER) or composite (SlawIlk.COMPLEX, SlawIlk.NUMBER_VECTOR, SlawIlk.COMPLEX_VECTOR, SlawIlk.MULTI_VECTOR, SlawIlk.NUMBER_ARRAY, SlawIlk.COMPLEX_ARRAY, SlawIlk.VECTOR_ARRAY, SlawIlk.COMPLEX_VECTOR_ARRAY and SlawIlk.MULTI_VECTOR_ARRAY). For the latter, the numeric ilk refers, transitively, to the numeric ilk of their components, which will always be of the same ilk (all numbers, or all vectors, and so on) and have the same numeric ilk (NumericIlk.INT8, NumericIlk.UNT32, etc.).

    • isNumber

      public final boolean isNumber()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is equal to NUMBER. Note that isNumber() implies isNumeric(), but that not all numeric slawx are numbers.

    • isNumber

      public final boolean isNumber(NumericIlk ni)
      Checks whether this Slaw is a number (using isNumber()) and that its numeric ilk equals ni.

    • isComplex

      public final boolean isComplex()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.COMPLEX

    • isVector

      public final boolean isVector()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk corresponds to a vector, regardless of its components' kind. Multivectors are also included in this family. The components of a vector can be either numbers or complex numbers, while multivectors can have only numbers. In all cases, components are homogeneous: they have the same ilk and the same numeric ilk.
      See Also:
      • SlawIlk.isVector()

    • isNumberVector

      public final boolean isNumberVector()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.NUMBER_VECTOR

    • isComplexVector

      public final boolean isComplexVector()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.COMPLEX_VECTOR

    • isMultivector

      public final boolean isMultivector()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.MULTI_VECTOR

    • isArray

      public final boolean isArray()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk corresponds to an array, regardless of its components' kind. Components are numeric (number, complex or vectorial) and homogeneous, both in ilk and numeric ilk.
      See Also:
      • SlawIlk.isArray()

    • isNumberArray

      public final boolean isNumberArray()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.NUMBER_ARRAY

    • isComplexArray

      public final boolean isComplexArray()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.COMPLEX_ARRAY

    • isNumberVectorArray

      public final boolean isNumberVectorArray()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.VECTOR_ARRAY

    • isByteArray

      public final boolean isByteArray()
      Byte arrays are Slawx with ilk SlawIlk.NUMBER_ARRAY and numeric ilk NumericIlk.INT8 or NumericIlk.UNT8. We single them out because they're able to emit a native by Java byte array (see emitByteArray()

    • isComplexVectorArray

      public final boolean isComplexVectorArray()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.COMPLEX_VECTOR_ARRAY

    • isMultivectorArray

      public final boolean isMultivectorArray()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.MULTI_VECTOR_ARRAY

    • isCons

      public final boolean isCons()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.CONS

    • isList

      public final boolean isList()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.LIST

    • isMap

      public final boolean isMap()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.MAP

    • isProtein

      public final boolean isProtein()
      Checks whether this Slaw's ilk is SlawIlk.PROTEIN. Slawx with this ilk can be down-casted to Protein using toProtein().

    • emitBoolean

      public abstract boolean emitBoolean()
      When this Slaw has ilk SlawIlk.BOOL, emits the corresponding boolean value it encapsulates. Otherwise, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

    • emitString

      public abstract String emitString()
      When this Slaw has ilk SlawIlk.STRING, emits the corresponding String value it encapsulates. Otherwise, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

    • emitLong

      public abstract long emitLong()
      When this Slaw has ilk SlawIlk.NUMBER, emits the corresponding value it encapsulates, cast to a long. Otherwise, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

      If the numeric ilk of this Slaw is either NumericIlk.FLOAT32 or NumericIlk.FLOAT64, a loss of precision may occurr, equivalent to the one implied in a conversion from float or double to long. Therefore, for those numeric ilks, it's safer to use emitDouble() instead.

      Likewise, for slaw numbers of numeric ilk NumericIlk.UNT64, the eight bytes representing its value will be interpreted as the 2-complement representation of the returned long; thus, unless you're sure that this Slaw's value is below Long.MAX_VALUE, it is safer to use emitBigInteger() for UNT64 numbers.

    • emitInt

      public abstract int emitInt()
      Equivalent to downcasting the result of emitLong() to int. If the numerick ilk of this Slaw corresponds to an integral 64-bit type, or a floating point, there's a risk of losing precision due to the coercion. There's also a potential coercion problem for NumericIlk.UNT32, in that the bit pattern of the unsigned int will be reinterpreted as a signed value.

      If this Slaw is not a number, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

    • emitShort

      public abstract short emitShort()
      Equivalent to downcasting the result of emitLong() to short. If the numerick ilk of this Slaw corresponds to an integral 64-bit or 32-bit type, or a floating point, there's a risk of losing precision due to the coercion. There's also a potential coercion problem for NumericIlk.UNT16, in that the bit pattern of the unsigned int will be reinterpreted as a signed value.

      If this Slaw is not a number, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

    • emitByte

      public abstract byte emitByte()
      Equivalent to downcasting the result of emitLong() to byte. If the numeric ilk of this Slaw corresponds to an integer wider than 8 bits, or a floating point, there's a risk of losing precision due to the coercion. There's also a potential coercion problem for NumericIlk.UNT8, in that the bit pattern of the unsigned int will be reinterpreted as a signed value.

      If this Slaw is not a number, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

    • emitDouble

      public abstract double emitDouble()
      When this Slaw has ilk SlawIlk.NUMBER, emits the corresponding value it encapsulates, cast to a double. Otherwise, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

      If the numeric ilk of this Slaw corresponds to an integral numeric type, a loss of precision may occurr, equivalent to the one implied in a conversion from an Java integer type to double. Therefore, for those numeric ilks, it's safer to use emitLong() or emitBigInteger() instead.

    • emitFloat

      public abstract float emitFloat()
      Equivalent to downcasting the result of emitDouble() to a float. There's a risk of losing precision if this Slaw's numeric ilk is NumericIlk.FLOAT64 or any integral ilk.

      If this Slaw is not a number, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

    • emitBigInteger

      public abstract BigInteger emitBigInteger()
      When this Slaw has ilk SlawIlk.NUMBER, emits the corresponding value it encapsulates, cast to a BigInteger. Otherwise, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

      If the numeric ilk of this Slaw corresponds to an integral type, this method is guaranteed to return the actual value, without losing precision. But, if the numeric ilk of this Slaw is either NumericIlk.FLOAT32 or NumericIlk.FLOAT64, a loss of precision may occur, equivalent to the one implied in a conversion from float or double to long. Therefore, for those numeric ilks, it's safer to use emitDouble() instead.

    • emitByteArray

      public final byte[] emitByteArray()
      Byte arrays (see isByteArray() can emit their data as a native Java array.

      This method returns a copy of said data, or throws an UnsupportedOperationException if this slaw isn't a byte array.

    • unsafeEmitByteArray

      public abstract byte[] unsafeEmitByteArray()
      This method works like emitByteArray(), but without copying. It's a performance hack that you shouldn't use unless you're completely sure that you will never ever modify the contents of the returned array.

    • car

      public abstract Slaw car()
      When this Slaw has ilk SlawIlk.CONS, SlawIlk.COMPLEX or SlawIlk.LIST (and, in the latter case, corresponds to a non-empty list), the first component of the Slaw is returned. Otherwise, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

      When supported, this operation returns the same value as nth(0).

      See Also:
      • cdr()

    • cdr

      public abstract Slaw cdr()
      When this Slaw has ilk SlawIlk.CONS, SlawIlk.COMPLEX or SlawIlk.LIST (and, in the latter case, corresponds to a non-empty list), the second component of the Slaw is returned (where, in the case of lists, the 'second component' here means the list of all elements except the first one). Otherwise, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

      When supported, this operation returns the same value as nth(1) for conses and complex numbers, and a list consisting of all elements but the first when this Slaw is a list.

      See Also:
      • car()

    • dimension

      public abstract int dimension()
      When this Slaw is a vector or multivector, its dimension will be returned. Arrays have the dimension of their components. For other ilks, this method returns 0.

    • count

      public abstract int count()
      Number of sub-slaw contained in this Slaw instance. As a degenerate case, this method returns 1 for atomic ilks. For complex numbers and conses, it returns 2; for vectors, a number between 2 and 4 (the same as the dimension), and one between 4 and 32 for multivectors (i.e., 2 to the dimension of the multivector). For lists, this is the number of elements and, for maps, the number of keys. Finally, if this Slaw has as ilk SlawIlk.PROTEIN, this method will return 0.

    • nth

      public abstract Slaw nth(int n)
      Access to the nth sub-slaw of this Slaw instance, where n is a zero-based index. This method is guaranteed to succeed and return a non-null value provided n is less than the value returned by count(). If that's not the case, an (unchecked) IndexOutOfBoundsException is thrown.

      For complex numbers and conses, nth(0) and nth(1) are equivalent to car() and cdr(), respectively. For vectors and multivectors, it returns the corresponding component, while for lists it accesses the nth element. If this Slaw is a map, the returning Slaw is a cons composed of the nth key and value.

      Proteins have no sub-slaw.

      This method, together with count(), is used to implement all the list-related methods in the Slaw interface. Therefore, its semantics constitute the way slawx of any kind are viewed as lists of subslawx.

    • indexOf

      public final int indexOf(Slaw elem, Slaw... elems)
      Looks for elem and all elems among this Slaw's sub-slawx. The search is performed in order, and the method returns the index of the first argument, if all of them are present. For this method to return anything other than -1, all slawx must appear among this Slaw's sub-slawx in the given order, but not necessarily contiguously.

      Thus, it is always the case that the return value is less that count(), and that, whenever this method returns a non-negative value, e.equals(indexOf(e)) is true.

      The result will always be -1 if any of the arguments is null (Slaw never contains null sub-slawx).

    • contains

      public final boolean contains(Slaw elem, Slaw... elems)
      Checks whether indexOf(elem, elems) > -1.
      See Also:
      • indexOf(Slaw, Slaw...)

    • emitList

      public final List<Slaw> emitList()
      Creates a list with all of the sub-slawx of this Slaw. This method uses nth(int) to construct the list, so a non-null value will always be returned (albeit in some occasions it may be an empty List), even if this Slaw is not of ilk SlawIlk.LIST.

    • emitArray

      public final Slaw[] emitArray()
      Like emitList(), but returning an array.

    • emitList

      public final List<Slaw> emitList(int begin, int end)
      Returns a slice of the list constructed by emitList().

      The slice contains elements beginning at index begin and ending at either end-1 or count()-1 if end>count(). If endinvalid input: '<'=begin, an empty list is returned. Negative end or begin values are transformed to positive values by subtracting them from count().

    • iterator

      public final Iterator<Slaw> iterator()
      An iterator traversing this Slaw's subslawx sequentially, using nth(int). This method makes Slaw an implementation of Iterable, and allows you to rewrite old-style loops of the form: 
         for (int i = 0; i invalid input: '<' s.count(); ++i) f(s.nth(i));
      as 
         for (Slaw ss : s) f(ss);
      And of course you can also use Iterator's interface on the the returned value, which, however, does not support the Iterator.remove operation (because Slaw instances are immutable).
      Specified by:
      iterator in interface Iterable<Slaw>

    • emitMap

      public abstract Map<Slaw,Slaw> emitMap()
      Converts a Slaw of ilk SlawIlk.MAP to a Java native map. If this Slaw is a list and all its elements are conses, they're taken as key/value pairs; otherwise, its elements are interpreted as alternating keys and values (discarding the last one if the number of elements is odd), and a corresponding map is constructed. Pairs are taken as representing a key (the car) and its value (the cdr). For all other Slaw ilks, an empty map is returned.

    • find

      public abstract Slaw find(Slaw key)
      This method is equivalent to calling get(key) on the map returned by emitMap(), which see.

    • toProtein

      public final Protein toProtein()
      Convenience method down-casting this Slaw to a Protein instance. If this slaw's ilk is not SlawIlk.PROTEIN, an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

    • equals

      public final boolean equals(Object o)
      Equality predicate. This Slaw will only be equal to another Slaw instance of the same ilk and numeric ilk that, moreover, encapsulates the same underlying value, recursively.

      Note that this notion of equality is stronger than the one that could be induced by, say, just comparing emitted values, or the subslawx of the two Slaw instances being tested. It is thus possible for two different Slaw to have, for instance, the same sub-slawx and yet be different (one could be a list of pairs and the other one a map), or to return the same value in emitLong() and yet have different numeric ilks (and, hence, classified as distinct slawx by this predicate).

      Overrides:
      equals in class Object

    • toString

      public String toString()
      String representation of this Slaw, strictly for debugging purposes. No guarantees are made about the format of this representation, except that it will be human-readable (FSVO human). Please, don't rely on any of its other properties, because all of them may change in future versions without warning.
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object

    • withNumericIlk

      public abstract Slaw withNumericIlk(NumericIlk ilk)
      If this Slaw is numeric, returns a copy of it with all its components coerced to the provided numeric ilk. For non-number Slaw instances (i.e., those that answer false to the predicate isNumeric()), this method throws an UnsupportedOperationException.

    • slawEquals

      public abstract boolean slawEquals(Slaw s)
      Auxiliarly method used by equals.

    • cons

      public static Slaw cons(Slaw car, Slaw cdr)
      A factory method constructing a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.CONS out of its two components. Both arguments must be non-null; otherwise, an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

    • list

      public static SlawList list(Slaw... s)
      A factory method constructing a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.LIST out of its components. Null arguments are discarded. Thus, Slaw.list(null) returns an empty Slaw list, as does Slaw.list().

    • list

      public static Slaw list(List<? extends Slaw> s)
      A factory method constructing a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.LIST from a native Java list. Null elements of s are discarded. If its argument is null, it returns an empty Slaw list.

    • list

      public static Slaw list(Collection<? extends HasToSlaw> s)

    • map

      public static Slaw map(Slaw... kvs)
      A factory method constructing a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.MAP from an explicit list of slawx. The arguments are interpreted as alternating keys and values. If any of the slawx in a key/value pair is null, the whole pair is skipped.

    • map

      public static Slaw map(List<Slaw> kvs)
      A factory method constructing a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.MAP from a list of slawx. The arguments' elements are interpreted as alternating keys and values. If any of the slawx in a key/value pair is null, the whole pair is skipped.

    • map

      public static SlawMap map(Map<Slaw,Slaw> m)
      A factory method constructing a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.LIST from a native Java map. If any of the slawx in a key/value pair is null, the whole pair is skipped. When m is null, an empty Slaw map is returned.

    • protein

      public static Protein protein(Slaw descrips, Slaw ingests)
      A factory method creating a Protein. Calling this method is equivalent to calling protein(descrips, ingests, null) (i.e., it constructs a protein without raw data).

    • protein

      public static Protein protein(Slaw descrips, Slaw ingests, byte[] data)
      A factory method constructing a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.PROTEIN out of its three components: descrips, ingests and raw data. Any argument can be null, denoting, respectively, a protein without descrips, ingests or raw data. There are no restrictions on the ilk of descrips and ingests.

    • nil

      public static Slaw nil()
      A factory method creating a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.NIL. All nil slawx are equal under the equals(java.lang.Object) predicate, but no guarantees are made regarding the equality, under ==, of the instances returned by different calls to this method.

    • bool

      public static Slaw bool(boolean v)
      A factory method creating a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.BOOL. All true slawx are equal under the equals(java.lang.Object) predicate, as are all false ones, but no guarantees are made regarding the equality, under ==, of the instances returned by different calls to this method.

    • string

      public static SlawString string(String s)
      A factory method creating a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.STRING. When serialized, Slaw strings are always encoded using UTF-8.

    • int8

      public static Slaw int8(int n)
      Equivalent to calling Slaw.number(SlawIlk.INT8, n).

    • int16

      public static Slaw int16(int n)
      Equivalent to calling Slaw.number(SlawIlk.INT16, n).

    • int32

      public static Slaw int32(int n)
      Equivalent to calling Slaw.number(SlawIlk.INT32, n).

    • int64

      public static Slaw int64(long n)
      Equivalent to calling Slaw.number(SlawIlk.INT64, n).

    • unt8

      public static Slaw unt8(int n)
      Equivalent to calling Slaw.number(SlawIlk.UNT8, n).

    • unt16

      public static Slaw unt16(int n)
      Equivalent to calling Slaw.number(SlawIlk.UNT16, n).

    • unt32

      public static Slaw unt32(long n)
      Equivalent to calling Slaw.number(SlawIlk.UNT32, n).

    • unt64

      public static Slaw unt64(long n)
      Equivalent to calling Slaw.number(SlawIlk.UNT64, n).

    • unt64

      public static Slaw unt64(BigInteger n)
      A factory method creating a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.NUMBER and numeric ilk NumericIlk.UNT64. Only the 8 less significant bytes of n are considered, and they're interpreted as representing a positive number. When your Slaw's value is in the lower half of UNT64's domain, you can just use unt64(long) instead.

    • float32

      public static Slaw float32(float n)
      Equivalent to calling Slaw.number(SlawIlk.FLOAT32, n). Note that that means the overload of Slaw.number taking a double as second argument.

    • float64

      public static Slaw float64(double n)
      Equivalent to calling Slaw.number(SlawIlk.FLOAT64, n). Note that that means the overload of Slaw.number taking a double as second argument.

    • number

      public static Slaw number(NumericIlk ni, long value)
      Factoring method constructing a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.NUMBER and the given numeric ilk and value. If n is the width, in bytes, of the requested numeric ilk (as returned by ni.width()), only the n less significant bytes of value are used. When ni is signed, those bytes' bits are interpreted as a 2-complement bit pattern, and the other way around: passing a negative value when constructing an unsigned ilk will reinterpret the value's 2-complement bits as denoting a positive value. All that just means that, as long as you pass an integer value to this method which is within the range of the desired numeric ilk, things will work as expected.

      The numeric ilk NumericIlk.UNT64 is a corner case, because to represent the upper half of its domanin using Java long values you need to use negative values and keep in mind their actual bit representation. An alternative is to use unt64(BigInteger), which will be less error-prone in exchange of a bit of performance.

      If you want to construct a number of a non-integral numeric ilk, you should be using the overload of this method that takes a double as second argument, to avoid the loss of precision involved in converting from long to double.

    • number

      public static Slaw number(NumericIlk ni, double value)
      Factoring method constructing a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.NUMBER and the given numeric ilk and value. Althought you can call this method with any numeric ilk, the common case will be to use it when creating Slaw number with numeric ilk NumericIlk.FLOAT32 or NumericIlk.FLOAT64. When called with an integral ilk as its first argument, this method behaves as number(ni, (long)value), and you'll need to care about the possible rounding errors that the cast can produce.

    • complex

      public static Slaw complex(Slaw re, Slaw im)
      A factory method constructing a Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.COMPLEX out of its real and imaginary parts. Both arguments must be non-null and have ilk SlawIlk.NUMBER; otherwise, an IllegalArgumentException is thrown. They don't need to have the same numeric ilk, though. When the numeric ilks of the real and imaginary parts differ, the numeric ilk of the result is the one returned by NumericIlk.dominantIlk(java.util.List<com.oblong.jelly.NumericIlk>), which see (basically, a widening numerical conversion one is used).

      For instance, the result of calling complex(int8(1), float32(2)) will be a complex Slaw with numeric ilk FLOAT32.

    • vector

      public static Slaw vector(Slaw x, Slaw y)
      A factory method constructing a 2-dimensional vector Slaw out of its components. Both arguments must be non-null and have ilk the same ilk, which must be either SlawIlk.NUMBER or SlawIlk.COMPLEX; otherwise, an IllegalArgumentException is thrown. The ilk of the resulting vector will be either SlawIlk.NUMBER_VECTOR or SlawIlk.COMPLEX_VECTOR.

      They arguments don't need to have the same numeric ilk, though. When the numeric ilks of the given components differ, the numeric ilk of the result is the one returned by NumericIlk.dominantIlk(java.util.List<com.oblong.jelly.NumericIlk>), which see (basically, a widening numerical conversion one is used). For instance, the result of calling 

         vector(complex(int8(1), float32(2)),
          complex(int16(3), unt16(4)))
      will be a vector Slaw with ilk SlawIlk.COMPLEX_VECTOR and numeric ilk NumericIlk.FLOAT32.

    • vector

      public static Slaw vector(Slaw x, Slaw y, Slaw z)
      A factory method constructing a 3-dimensional vector Slaw out of its components. The semantics and constraints on its arguments as the same as those of vector(Slaw,Slaw), which see.

    • vector

      public static Slaw vector(Slaw x, Slaw y, Slaw z, Slaw w)
      A factory method constructing a 4-dimensional vector Slaw out of its components. The semantics and constraints on its arguments as the same as those of vector(Slaw,Slaw), which see.

    • vector

      public static Slaw vector(float[] value)

    • vector

      public static Slaw vector(double[] value)

    • vector

      public static Slaw vector(int[] value)

    • multivector

      public static Slaw multivector(Slaw... cs)
      A factory method constructing a Slaw multivector out of its components. The number of arguments must be 4, 8, 16 or 32 (for a multivector of dimension 2, 3, 4 or 5), and all must be non-null and have ilk SlawIlk.NUMBER; otherwise an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

      The arguments don't need to have the same numeric ilk, though. When the numeric ilks of the given components differ, the numeric ilk of the result is the one returned by NumericIlk.dominantIlk(java.util.List<com.oblong.jelly.NumericIlk>), which see (basically, a widening numerical conversion one is used).

    • array

      public static Slaw array(Slaw[] sx)
      A factory method constructing a non-empty numeric Slaw array out of its components. The given array must have at least one non-null element; otherwise, an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

      Calling this method is equivalent to calling array(sx[0],sx[1],...sx[sx.length - 1]). See array(Slaw,Slaw...) for details.

    • array

      public static Slaw array(float[] array)

    • array

      public static Slaw array(byte[] elems, boolean signed)
      A factory method creating an array of INT8 or UNT8. The given data is copied, so modifying it won't modify the returned slaw.

    • array

      public static Slaw array(Slaw n, Slaw... ns)
      A factory method constructing a non-empty numeric Slaw array out of its components. At least one of the arguments must be non-null (nulls are skipped), and all non-null arguments must have the same ilk (otherwise an IllegalArgumentException is thrown). That common ilk must be numeric (i.e., return true for SlawIlk.isNumeric()) but not an array ilk (i.e. return false for SlawIlk.isArray()). In addition, all components must have the same dimension. The ilk of the resulting array is derived from that that of its components in the natural way, and can therefore be any of the array ilks (as defined by the predicate SlawIlk.isArray()).

      As is the case with all other composite numeric Slaw constructors, the arguments don't need to have the same numeric ilk, though. When the numeric ilks of the given components differ, the numeric ilk of the result is the one returned by NumericIlk.dominantIlk(java.util.List<com.oblong.jelly.NumericIlk>), which see (basically, a widening numerical conversion one is used).

    • array

      public static Slaw array(List<Slaw> sx)
      A factory method constructing a non-empty numeric Slaw array out of its components. At least one of the elements of the given list must be non-null (nulls are skipped), and all non-null arguments must have the same ilk (otherwise an IllegalArgumentException is thrown). See the two other array constructors for further restrictions on those elements, if any.

    • emptyNumberArray

      public static Slaw emptyNumberArray(NumericIlk ni)
      Returns a new empty array with ilk SlawIlk.NUMBER_ARRAY and the given numeric ilk.

    • emptyComplexArray

      public static Slaw emptyComplexArray(NumericIlk ni)
      Returns a new empty array with ilk SlawIlk.COMPLEX_ARRAY and the given numeric ilk.

    • emptyVectorArray

      public static Slaw emptyVectorArray(NumericIlk ni, int dim)
      Returns a new empty array with ilk SlawIlk.VECTOR_ARRAY and the given numeric ilk and dimension, which must be between 2 and 4.

    • emptyComplexVectorArray

      public static Slaw emptyComplexVectorArray(NumericIlk ni, int dim)
      Returns a new empty array with ilk SlawIlk.COMPLEX_VECTOR_ARRAY and the given numeric ilk and dimension, which must be between 2 and 4.

    • emptyMultiVectoryArray

      public static Slaw emptyMultiVectoryArray(NumericIlk ni, int dim)
      Returns a new empty array with ilk SlawIlk.MULTI_VECTOR_ARRAY and the given numeric ilk and dimension, which must be between 2 and 5.

    • array

      public static Slaw array(SlawIlk ilk, NumericIlk ni, int dimension)
      Generic empty array constructor. The ilk must be of kind array, and the dimension one of the accepted values for the given ilk.

    • toSlaw

      public Slaw toSlaw()
      Specified by:
      toSlaw in interface HasToSlaw
